A little like Rimworld, a little like tower defense. But why not. As other reviews have mentioned, the base game feels either unfinished or too short. Despite that, I still managed to get 50 hours of fun out of it without mods. There are at least three distinct playthroughs, thanks to the three different maps/biomes and three unique scenarios.
What I highly recommend is visiting the workshop. Mods make this game significantly better. New food, equip, hygiene needs, more survivors... Even so it might start to feel repetitive after a few runs. 
So if you thinking about buying, buy it in sale, but it is definitely worth trying.

I've sunk a great deal of time into this game, and I'll say that I very much enjoy it. I legitimately don't get tired of building up new colonies, cranking up the difficulty, and seeing how I can weather various raids.

Many lob the critique of it being "3D RimWorld," and I think that is warranted. The game has much of the same UI as RimWorld, similar concepts, and similar mechanics, including periodic raids that scale in power. I do enjoy the added depth of the 3D space, and being able to build tall as you unlock additional technologies is a nice touch.

However, there are parts of this game that strike me as half-baked, and I've listed some of them below:

-There are remarkably few options for weapons and clothing, with late-game weapons being one that shoots far, one that shoots close, and one that stuns. The late game clothing could do with a bit more variety, perhaps with set bonuses that enhance certain abilities beyond just cold resistance and defense.

-The characters move with agonizing slowness. Playing the game in real-time is a nightmare, as it takes between five and ten seconds for characters to do actions as simple as get out of bed or disengage from a task. Their movement speed is also horrendous, and they often end up slowly jogging to a distance objective, taking one whack at it, then running back to eat a meal. I recognize that the developers implemented the "fast feet" modifier that you can optionally implement, but doing something as simple as allowing settlers to stock meals in their inventory or just making them move faster at baseline would be big improvement.

-The late game drags for all but the Robots and Guardians DLC. You will find yourself spending hours upon hours just waiting for an in-game event to pop, with little variation in interstitial events through the rather thin exploration mechanic.

-Crafting of mid- and high-tier components, like electronics and AI cores, takes forever. There is one research that allows you to use 3D printers to manufacture some mid-tier components via 3D printers, and I think that should be standard for all playthroughs.

-Certain quality of life improvements, like automating colonist actions during raids (such as setting battlestations that all colonists report to in the event of an attack) would make it less of a chore to fight back enemies and make it a legitimate test of your defenses. As it stands, it feels like herding cats to get everybody back to base without getting rocked by your colonists' own stupid pathing.

-More variation in player skills. Some of the modded characters do a nice job of this, with significant and noted advantages for certain skillsets among chosen colonists. If somebody is going to be a designated crafter, make them crank through crafting projects in half the time of others with a corresponding debuff to balance it out.

-Certain bugs still need fixing. As much as I love the ability to build vertically, this game is just not built to optimize that mechanic. You can't make a three-level stairwell without the game bugging out on you and making certain roof or wall segments impossible to build. The elevator would benefit from a setting where you can manually cap how many floors it goes up, as opposed to continuing upward infinitely (unless you move it over a tile, construct the ceiling and roof on the top floor, and then move it back).

For all of my noted problems, this game has great bones. I know Paradox recently purchased this game, and I sincerely hope they give it some love. Even straightforward (albeit significant) changes like quest variety and progression pacing would go a long way.

‚≠ê Stranded: Alien Dawn ‚Äì Review (Recommended)

Playtime: ~60 hours

Verdict: ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÖ‚òÜ (8/10) ‚Äì A beautiful, engaging colony-survival sim that‚Äôs easy to get into and rewarding to master.

What it is:
Stranded: Alien Dawn puts you in charge of a small group of survivors stranded on an alien world. Your job: keep them alive, build a functioning colony, research new tech, and deal with whatever the planet throws at you ‚Äî from alien wildlife to mental breakdowns.

It plays like a mix of RimWorld, Surviving Mars, and The Sims (but in space) ‚Äî with detailed survivor management, base building, and survival priorities.

üëç The Good

Satisfying colony management: Clear task priorities, intuitive building, and lots of control over how your survivors spend their time.

Personalized survivors: Each character has unique traits, moods, and skills ‚Äî they actually feel human, not just generic workers.

Beautiful presentation: Great lighting, alien landscapes, and weather effects. Watching your base evolve from a few huts to a full-on colony is genuinely rewarding.

Flexible difficulty: You can play chill, focus on building, or turn up the pressure with constant raids and extreme weather.

Replayable: Different scenarios, biomes, and survivor combos keep things fresh for multiple runs.

üëé The Not-So-Good

Shallow compared to RimWorld: Systems don‚Äôt interlock as deeply ‚Äî fewer emergent stories and less mod support (for now).

Pacing dips mid-game: Once your base is stable, things can slow down a bit until new threats or goals appear.

Console/UI quirks: On controller, menus can be a little clunky; best experience is with mouse and keyboard.

‚öôÔ∏è Overall Thoughts

Stranded: Alien Dawn doesn‚Äôt reinvent the colony-sim wheel, but it polishes it to a nice shine. It‚Äôs approachable, gorgeous, and just deep enough to hook you for hours. Perfect for players who want the survival/management challenge without diving into the brutal complexity of RimWorld.

Recommended for:
Fans of base-builders, survival management, or anyone who loves watching small stories emerge from everyday survival chaos.
Many options, hunt, farm, explore, find survivors, develop tech.

Pros:

Base-building and micromanagement that scratches that survival itch

Expeditions that make you feel like you‚Äôre doing something productive while your base burns down

Mechs. My colonists drive mechs. That alone deserves a thumbs up.

Cons:

Enemies? Yeah, it‚Äôs just angry wildlife. Every fight feels like ‚ÄúJurassic Park: The Indie Game‚Äù

No organ harvesting, no drug empires ‚Äî basically no RimWorld-level chaos

Zero factions, zero trading, and this planet must be the Bermuda Triangle of space because everyone crashes here but no one leaves

I‚Äôd love DLC that adds human or alien factions ‚Äî friendly ones to trade with, hostile ones to shoot at, and maybe a few who just want to sell me questionable substances. Give me raids, diplomacy, betrayal ‚Äî I want drama!

For now, it‚Äôs a chill, polished, alien RimWorld-lite with mechs. And I can live with that.

This is... this is Rimworld. I don't mean "this reminds me of Rimworld" or "this is a similar sort of experience to Rimworld", it's the same game with nicer graphics and some features left off. It feels weird to give a thumbs down to a game I've put over 100 hours into, but my honest review is "Go play Rimworld instead." If you love that game, you sadly won't find anything new here. If you've never played it, you're better off experiencing the original.
I guess if Rimworld's low-fi graphics were bugging you, or maybe you thought its gameplay was a bit too detailed, this game is probably for you. For my money, I find myself missing a number of Rimworld's features and in-depth management, and my NES-era brain stopped being impressed by shiny graphics upgrades a long time ago.

Very odd game. You want to like the game and certain aspects are enjoyable, but there are too many flaws in the game to really be able to play it for long. These issues only get worse as you progress. It has a lot of good ideas but none of it has been implemented well, and there are a few bugs and quirks that add to the frustration.

Unfortunately this is one of those games that feels unfinished. With a little polish, a little extra effort, this could have been fantastic. As it is, it feels bare bones and, like many colony sims, quickly devolves in a lot of micro management. It desperately lacks any depth or width. There are the bare bones of a story, there is a tech tree, there are things to do, but it all becomes a big hassle. With some trial and error, surviving the first winter, when there is no easily accessible food except for animals, becomes easy. All you need is a fridge, or, preferably, a freezer. Because all vegetables, fruits, and the like, spoil if not stored properly. Fair enough. But manure ALSO spoils and you need manure to fertilize the fields. Especially if there are crops which you desperately need, so want to grow quickly. But there are too many tasks, and you have so few people available, so gathering manure and storing it (in a freezer no less!) falls by the wayside. So then you are inundated with messages that your manure is spoling/has spoiled. Annoyances like that take up way too much of the game. The native species randomly spawn attacks that are relatively easily fended off, at least at the lower difficulty level, even with handweapons. But those same critters can destroy even concrete walls if left unattended for too long, for instance because they're out of line-of-sight while your people are fighting off the rest of the attack. So what's the point of spending a huge amount of time and effort in making concrete? Most of the 'story' consists of simple 'click one option out of 2/4 and lead to very little in reward. In the 'crashlanded' scenario, the cause of the crash is never addressed, aside from some rumours about it. A wasted opportunity. None of the conversations, even those that are only a few lines, are voiced, making them even less immersive. That you have to research in the 'crashlanded' scenario, makes some sense, that you need to do the same in the 'outpost' scenario, a lot less so, nor does it appear to be addressed even by a line, like, circumstances are different from what we thought, we need to adapt. In addition, the tech tree is randomly truncated, with random inspirations driving further research, but some options available in one playthrough but not others (being able to 3D-print electronic circuits would have been expected in the outpost scenario, but over 2 years in, I didn't see it. You can build defensive turrets, but since attacks can be countered by putting your crew on alert, and because it appeared the turrets wouldn't be able to fire over walls and have only about the same range as the personal firearms of the crew, I didn't even bother to waste resources on that. Whenever you build something, it almost immediately breaks down anyway and then requires precious resources to repair. Tending animals seems to be a waste of time, other than having a ready supply of manure to be ignored. You can easily just hunt any animals nearby, without having to waste time and resources to feed them. Twice I had issues feeding my animals. In one playthrough, there was plenty of the right kind of food sitting in a through, but one dog inexplicably hungry. Since that was the first time I had any animals, I neglected to feed it manually. Big mistake. It ended up going berserk with hunger, despite the aforementioned through being used by the second dog and that one having no issues whatsoever, which misled me to think the problem with the first dog would resolve itself naturally. So it goes berserk, and chases and attacks one of my people, which then suffers broken bones and so on. I hesitated to shoot the poor animal, hoping my crewmate would survive, which they did, but reading over the injury list made me feel very conflicted. Meanwhile, the dog had switched targets for no apparent reason after chasing my crewmate into a house and ended up attacking a large native creature. I thought it died doing that, but later on it was still there and no eating properly out of the very same through. Needless to say I didn't bother with dogs after that, which didn't really feel like they added anything anyway, and immediately intervened if for some reason an animal wasn't eating properly. I think the issue is with the accessability of the food, there needing to be some extra free space. But things like that pop up all over. There are no bugs, but everything takes just a bit too much work and quickly becomes repetitive and annoying. One of my crewmates fixes three light fixtures in a row, is done, another one breaks down. One crewmate almost finishes a harvest and then just goes home, leaving the harvested material to rot and the unharvested part of the field to go to waste, with no replanting, while fertilizing appears to happen randomly, perhaps because the field doesn't grow evenly, so some of the field remains unplanted and then it is IMPOSSIBLE to fertilize the other plants for some reason. Crewmates also move randomly between jobs, like they build part of a wall, then don't continue with the next part of that wall, even though the resources have been delivered, no, instead they move back into the house to lay down some carpet, which was a job that took years in one playthrough because there wasn't a steady supply of the material. I never even had a particularly large base IMHO, but there quickly appear to be too many jobs for too few people that take too much time. Having to micromanage all that isn't my idea of fun. If the game did some of that work, by identifying bottlenecks and giving those the needed priority, that'd be much more convenient. Finally, there doesn't really appear to be much of an endgame. In the 'crashlanded' scenario I constructed the radios and was able to get one (1) crewmember off at a time. That felt wrong, leaving behind a dwindling crew to fend off the incessant alien attacks and inevitable breakdowns. As for the 'outpost' scenario, I imagine there'd never be an end, you can't leave the outpost behind, unattended, it'll just get overrun. There's no way to build a base that'll take care of itself. So, what's the point of it all? But so much is already in place, with just a little more attention and TLC this could have been a great game. All the basic elements are there. If you do like these sort of games, you may still get some enjoyment out of it, but I do recommend getting it at a discount.

I guess if Rimworld's low-fi graphics were bugging you, or maybe you thought its gameplay was a bit too detailed, this game is probably for you. NOT RECOMMENDED if you are looking for a survivial crafter with depth and detail. 
Or for a survivial sim. Or for anything that the game description states prominently on the store page.

Instead, what you get is a rather uninspired tower defense game, with crafting, survivial, sim, and everything else taking a very far back seat.

Animal attacks happen near-regularly on a timer. Each subsequent attack is by a larger group than the previous one. The more provisions you have stored, the even larger the group will be.  Also, the more defenses you have constructed, the larger the attack group seems to be.
This can go from initially a dozen animals to several hundreds quite quickly. 
Their pathfinding is VERY primitive, so you have to funnel them through a narrow and long constructed defensive path. 
And that's all the finesse there is to it - no further tactical or strategic elements, at all.

I severely dislike tower defense of this type, so I reduced this gameplay element via a mod and by dropping to the lowest difficulty level.
And the remaining game was still uninspired, disappointing and annoying.

There are several undocumented and unclear mechanisms, and there are missable resources due to issue with the random map generation. Either alone will cause failure in the first or second game year. 
You will have to restart from scratch several times over - or read detailed guides in advance that spoil everything.
Some of these gameplay elements you can avoid if you know about them (e.g.: after a restart from scratch).
Others will force you to micro-manage around them very tediously, due to there being no way to make the survivors behave properly to avoid/neutralize them. Again, no finesse, at all.

Now, with both all those lessons learned, as well as with the tower defense element reduced via mods - the game is STILL uninspired!
You are locked into a mostly fixed path, entirely governed by how slow clothes tailoring, crafting and buildig construction is timed versus clothes and equipment wear&tear. Also, by how slow technology resesarch is.

There are no engaging discovery elements in this game - no incentive to explore the map (more the opposite), no technology or other surprises/discoveries/alternate paths.

In the end, this is a tedious slog - not an enjoyable game.

Which is a shame, as there is an incredible amount of detail in the game (excellent sim) - but it all gets buried and killed by the overwhemling mechanisms mentioned above - even if you reduce some of them via mods.

NOT RECOMMENDED, not even at a discount.

NOT RECOMMENDED if you are looking for a survivial crafter with depth and detail. 
Or for a survivial sim. Or for anything that the game description states prominently on the store page.

Instead, what you get is a rather uninspired tower defense game, with crafting, survivial, sim, and everything else taking a very far back seat.

Animal attacks happen near-regularly on a timer. Each subsequent attack is by a larger group than the previous one. The more provisions you have stored, the even larger the group will be.  Also, the more defenses you have constructed, the larger the attack group seems to be.
This can go from initially a dozen animals to several hundreds quite quickly. 
Their pathfinding is VERY primitive, so you have to funnel them through a narrow and long constructed defensive path. 
And that's all the finesse there is to it - no further tactical or strategic elements, at all.

I severely dislike tower defense of this type, so I reduced this gameplay element via a mod and by dropping to the lowest difficulty level.
And the remaining game was still uninspired, disappointing and annoying.

There are several undocumented and unclear mechanisms, and there are missable resources due to issue with the random map generation. Either alone will cause failure in the first or second game year. 
You will have to restart from scratch several times over - or read detailed guides in advance that spoil everything.
Some of these gameplay elements you can avoid if you know about them (e.g.: after a restart from scratch).
Others will force you to micro-manage around them very tediously, due to there being no way to make the survivors behave properly to avoid/neutralize them. Again, no finesse, at all.

Now, with both all those lessons learned, as well as with the tower defense element reduced via mods - the game is STILL uninspired!
You are locked into a mostly fixed path, entirely governed by how slow clothes tailoring, crafting and buildig construction is timed versus clothes and equipment wear&tear. Also, by how slow technology resesarch is.

There are no engaging discovery elements in this game - no incentive to explore the map (more the opposite), no technology or other surprises/discoveries/alternate paths.

In the end, this is a tedious slog - not an enjoyable game.

Which is a shame, as there is an incredible amount of detail in the game (excellent sim) - but it all gets buried and killed by the overwhemling mechanisms mentioned above - even if you reduce some of them via mods.

NOT RECOMMENDED, not even at a discount.
